facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2129 to 2132 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2129 to 2132 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated December 4, 1964 of Calcutta High Court in Tax Matters Nos. 69, 62 and 64 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 4, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Tax Matters Nos. 69, 62 and 64 of 1963.

facts.text: Wakf created by deed dated November 19, 1928 modified by deed dated July 5, 1930 by Golam Hossain Kasim Ariff.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed dated November 19, 1928 as modified by a deed of rectification dated July 5, 1930 one Golam Hossain Kasim Ariff, a muslim governed by the Hanafi School of the Mohammadan Law created a wakf in respect of his properties in Noormul Lohia Lane and Armenian Street in Calcutta.

facts.text: Wakf properties located in Noormul Lohia Lane and Armenian Street in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: created a wakf in respect of his properties in Noormul Lohia Lane and Armenian Street in Calcutta.

facts.text: Settlor Golam Hossain Kasim Ariff appointed himself sole Mutwalli for his life.

anchor.surface_text: The settler appointed himself as the sole Mutwalli for the term of his life and provided that after his death his widow Aisha Bibi and his sons would act as Mutwallis jointly.

facts.text: After settlor's death, widow Aisha Bibi and sons to act as Mutwallis jointly.

anchor.surface_text: The settler appointed himself as the sole Mutwalli for the term of his life and provided that after his death his widow Aisha Bibi and his sons would act as Mutwallis jointly.

facts.text: Settlor died on January 1, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The settler died on January 1, 1937. He left behind his widow Aisha Bibi and three sons who are the appellants before this Court.

facts.text: Settlor left behind widow Aisha Bibi and three sons who are the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: He left behind his widow Aisha Bibi and three sons who are the appellants before this Court. The wakf created was of the nature of Wakf-alal-aulad for the benefit of the settlers wife, children and their descendants.

facts.text: Wakf is Wakf-alal-aulad for benefit of settlor's wife, children and descendants.

anchor.surface_text: The wakf created was of the nature of Wakf-alal-aulad for the benefit of the settlers wife, children and their descendants.

facts.text: Clause 5 of wakf deed provides payment of 1/5 net income to settlor during life.

anchor.surface_text: After payment of all necessary out goings such as establishment charges, collections charges, revenue taxes, costs of repairs, law charges and other expenses for the upkeep and management of the said Wakf property, the Mutwalli or Mutwallis shall apply the net income of the said Wakf property as follows, viz. In payment to me during the term of my life of one-fifth of the said net income by monthly instalments.

facts.text: Clause 5 provides 1/6 net income to each son during their lives by monthly instalments.

anchor.surface_text: In payment to each of my sons during the respective terms of their lives one-sixth of the said net income by monthly instalments.

facts.text: Clause 5 provides 1/10 net income to wife Aisha Bibi during her life.

anchor.surface_text: In payment to my wife Aisha Bibi during the term of her life one tenth of the said net income by monthly instalments.

facts.text: Minors' shares under clause 5 to be invested after maintenance and education expenses until majority.

anchor.surface_text: The moneys payable as aforesaid to such of my sons as are minors shall until they attain the age of majority be respectively invested after defraying the expenses of their maintenance and education in proper securities or in landed property in Calcutta and such securities or property shall be made over to the said sons on their respectively attaining the age of majority.

facts.text: Ultimate benefit reserved for poor musalmans of Sunni community.

anchor.surface_text: The ultimate benefit in the case of complete intestacy of the descendants of the settlor was reserved for poor musalmans of Sunni community deserving help.

facts.text: Appellants paying income tax on amounts received from Mutwalli under wakf deed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are the beneficiaries under the deed of wakf were paying income tax on the amount which was being received by them in terms of that deed from the Mutwalli.

facts.text: Wealth Tax Act 27 of 1957 came into force in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1957 the Wealth Tax Act 27 of 1957, hereinafter called the Act, came into force.

facts.text: Appellants assessed to wealth tax for 1957-58 and 1958-59 on share in wakf estate.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment years 1957-58 and 1958-59 the appellants were not only assessed to income tax in respect of the income received by them from the wakf estate but were also assessed to Wealth tax by the Wealth Tax Officer on the basis that they had a share in the wakf estate.

facts.text: Wakf immovable property valued at 20 times annual municipal valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The total value of the immovable property belonging to the wakf estate was valued at 20 times the annual municipal valuation and 1/6th of the value of the immovable property along with other properties was taken to be the net wealth of each assessee.

facts.text: 1/6th value of wakf property taken as net wealth of each assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The total value of the immovable property belonging to the wakf estate was valued at 20 times the annual municipal valuation and 1/6th of the value of the immoveable property along with other properties was taken to be the net wealth of each assessee.

facts.text: Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Wealth Tax dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals were taken to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Wealth Tax but these were dismissed.

facts.text: Further appeals to Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: There were further appeals to the Income tax Appellate Tribunal where no dispute was raised as indeed it could not be raised with regard to the validity of the deed of wakf.

facts.text: ITAT held right of sons to receive share of rents and profits is property or interest in property under s.2(e).

anchor.surface_text: It was held that the right of the sons of the wakf to receive a share of the rents and profits of the wakf property was property or an interest in property and as it was not limited in enjoyment to a period of six years it fell within the definition of the term assets as defined by s. 2(e) of the Act.

facts.text: ITAT rejected contention that right is mere annuity under s.2(e)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants that the right of the beneficiaries under the deed of wakf was a mere right to an annuity as mentioned in s. 2(e)(iv) and was, therefore, not an asset assessable to wealth tax was rejected.

facts.text: ITAT rejected argument that allowances are maintenance not transferable under s.6(dd) TP Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third argument which had been raised before the Tribunal that the allowances under assessment were payable to the beneficiaries by way of maintenance were not transferable under s. 6(dd) of the Transfer of Property Act and therefore they had no market value, for inclusion in the net wealth was also refuted.

facts.text: ITAT directed valuation of life interest capitalised using Parks table at 6% rent security.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the quantum of valuation a direction was made that the value of the assessees life interest may be capitalised on the basis of the valuation table set out in Parks Principles and Practice of Valuations taking the rent security at 6.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court under s.27 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: On applications for referring the question of law, the following common question was referred to the High Court under s. 27 of the Act Whether on the facts and circumstances stated the right of the assessee to receive a specified share of the net income from the Wakf Estate is an asset the capitalised value of which is assessable to Wealth-tax?

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered question in affirmative in favour of revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The question was consequently answered in the affirmative and in favour of the revenue.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether the right of an assessee to receive a specified share of the net income from an estate in respect of which Wekf-alal-aulad has been created is an asset assessable to Wealth Tax

anchor.surface_text: important question, namely, whether the right of an assessee to receive a specified share of the net income from an estate in respect of which Wekf-alal-aulad has been created is an asset assessable to Wealth Tax.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances stated the right of the assessee to receive a specified share of the net income from the Wakf Estate is an asset the capitalised value of which is assessable to Wealth-tax?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances stated the right of the assessee to receive a specified share of the net income from the Wakf Estate is an asset the capitalised value of which is assessable to Wealth-tax?

issues.text: whether the right to receive an aliquot share of the net income of the properties which were made the subject matter of the wakf would be covered by the definition of assets within the meaning of s. 2 e of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is to be essentially decided whether the right to receive an aliquot share of the net income of the properties which were made the subject matter of the wakf would be covered by the definition of assets within the meaning of s. 2 e  of the Act.

arguments.claim: The right to receive a share of the income under a deed creating wakf-alal-aulad cannot be regarded to fall within the meaning of the word property even in its wide and extended sense.

anchor.surface_text: The principal argument of Mr. A.K. Sen for the appellants is that the right to receive a share of the income under a deed creating wakf-alal-aulad can, by not stretch of reasoning, be regarded to fall within the meaning of the word property even in its wide and extended sense.

arguments.court_reasoning: Property given widest meaning includes such interests; Shirur Mutt analogy.

arguments.claim: The aliquot share of income was reserved for the maintenance and support of the wakf and other beneficiaries during their lifetime; right to future maintenance measured by aliquot part, neither partible nor alienable, wholly personal, lacks attributes of property.

anchor.surface_text: The crux of the matter, according to Mr. Sen, is that the aliquot share of income under the deeds executed in the present case was reserved for the maintenance and support of the wakf and other beneficiaries during their lifetime.

arguments.court_reasoning: Even if for maintenance, still asset within s.2(e); deed not so limited.

arguments.claim: The right to receive a share of the income was a mere right to an annuity where the terms and conditions relating thereto precluded the commutation of any portion into a lump sum grant.

arguments.court_reasoning: Annuity given legal meaning from judicial interpretation, not popular/dictionary; not precluded.

arguments.claim: Assets includes property of every description, movable or immovable (subject to exclusions); covers the right to aliquot share of net income from wakf.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be essentially decided whether the right to receive an aliquot share of the net income of the properties which were made the subject matter of the wakf would be covered by the definition of assets within the meaning of s. 2 e  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Even if reserved for maintenance to preserve validity, the right to share of income is still an asset within s.2(e).

anchor.surface_text: On a proper construction of the relevant clauses in the wakf deed we are not satisfied that the aliquot share of the income provided for the beneficiaries was meant merely for their maintenance and support. But even on the assumption that it was so intended...

arguments.claim: Property in wide sense includes interests like Mahantship/Shebaitship.

anchor.surface_text: Reference may be made to one of them in which the question arose whether Mahantship or Shebaitship which combines elements of office and property would fall within the ambit of the word property as used in Article 19 1  f  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Following Bombay HC in Purshottam case: comprehensive definitions include all assets in net wealth.

anchor.surface_text: The only direct case on the point under consideration is a decision of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Wealth Tax, Bombay City v. Purshottam N. Amersey and Another... We are in entire concurrence with that view.

arguments.claim: s.7(1) valuation assumes hypothetical open market even for non-marketable assets.

anchor.surface_text: Such an argument was fully examined in the Bombay case... when the statute uses the words if sold in the open market it does not contemplate actual sale... the Tax Officer must assume that there is an open market...

arguments.claim: High Court view: even non-transferable asset has value via actuarial valuation as if saleable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that even if the asset of the nature under consideration was non-transferable and could not be sold in the open market it could not be said that such an asset had no value.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of property. Now property is a term of the widest import and subject to any limitation which the companytext may require, it signifies every possible

holdings.text: The right to receive an aliquot share of the net income of the properties which were made the subject matter of the wakf would be covered by the definition of assets within the meaning of s. 2(e) of the Act as it includes property of every description and there is no reason to give it a restricted meaning.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be essentially decided whether the right to receive an aliquot share of the net income of the properties which were made the subject matter of the wakf would be covered by the definition of assets within the meaning of s. 2 e  of the Act. There can be no difficulty if such a right can be regarded to be property giving that word the widest meaning as is contemplated by the language employed in the aforesaid clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide textual interpretation of 'property' in s.2(e); concurrence with Bombay HC precedent; rejects narrow view for wakf interests.

holdings.text: The definition of assets in s.2(e) and net wealth in s.2(m) are comprehensive and include every description of property subject to specified exceptions, imposing wealth tax on such interests under s.3.

anchor.surface_text: The only direct case on the point under consideration is a decision of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Wealth Tax, Bombay City v. Purshottam N. Amersey and Another... We are in entire concurrence with that view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Bombay HC in Purshottam case applying comprehensive scope of definitions under ss.2(e), 2(m), 3.

holdings.text: Even assuming the share of income was intended merely for maintenance and support or construed so to preserve wakf validity, it remains an asset under s.2(e) includible in net wealth.

anchor.surface_text: On a proper construction of the relevant clauses in the wakf deed we are not satisfied that the aliquot share of the income provided for the beneficiaries was meant merely for their maintenance and support. But even on the assumption that it was so intended...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical assumption; proper construction of deed; still falls within broad s.2(e) despite purpose.

holdings.text: The right to receive the share of income is not a mere right to an annuity under s.2(e) as the term 'annuity' bears its judicially interpreted legal meaning, not popular sense, and commutation is not precluded.

anchor.surface_text: A faint attempt was made to invoke the exception contained in s. 2 e  by suggesting that the right to receive a share of the income was a mere right to an annuity where the terms and conditions relating thereto precluded the commutation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal term interpretation from precedents; distinguishes aliquot share from annuity; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Even if non-transferable and unsaleable in open market, the asset has value under s.7(1) determined by hypothetical open market price via actuarial valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that even if the asset of the nature under consideration was non-transferable and could not be sold in the open market it could not be said that such an asset had no value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical market assumption per s.7(1); follows English precedents and Bombay HC.

holdings.text: The right to maintenance is not among exempt assets under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the right to maintenance was not one of the assets mentioned in s. 5 which alone entitled an assessee to claim exemption in respect of certain assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.5 exemptions; accepts Tribunal/High Court view.

holdings.text: The right is not incapable of valuation under s.7(1) as the Wealth Tax Officer must assume a hypothetical open market exists for such assets.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen has laid emphasis on the language of s. 7  1   of the Act and has contended that the right to a share in the income is not capable of any valuation and the price which it would fetch if sold in the open market,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(1) contemplates fictional market; supported by Bombay HC and English House of Lords precedent.

holdings.text: Allowances payable by way of maintenance are not excluded from wealth tax merely due to non-transferability under s.6(dd) TP Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third argument which had been raised before the Tribunal that the allowances under assessment were payable to the beneficiaries by way of maintenance were not transferable under s. 6 dd  of the Transfer of Property Act and therefore they had no market value, for inclusion in the net wealth was also refuted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-transferability irrelevant to asset status or valuation; hypothetical value applies.

anchor.surface_text: vide Vidya Varuthi v. Balusami Ayyar 1 . Wakfs companyld be divided into two classes public and  ii  private. A private wakf is one for the benefit of the  1  481.A. 302 atp. 312. settlors family and his descendants.

precedents.cited_proposition: Once it is declared that a particular property is wakf, the right of the wakf is extinguished and the ownership is transferred to the Mutawalli

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Karim Adenwalla v. Rahimabai 1 , a distinction was made between a settlor belonging to the Hanafi sect reserving for his own maintenance and support during his lifetime the income of the trust property and has reserving for his absolute use income of the whole of the property during his lifetime.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between reserving income for maintenance and support (not transferable) and reserving life interest (transferable under Transfer of Property Act)

precedents.citation: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

anchor.surface_text: It was observed in the Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1  that there was numberreason why that word should number be given a liberal and wide companynotation and should number be extended to those well recognised types of interests which had the insignia or characeristics of proprietary right.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Shri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: Property should be given a wide connotation including interests like Mahantship or Shebaitship with proprietary characteristics

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Wealth Fax, Bombay City v. Purshottam N. Amersey and Another 2

anchor.surface_text: The only direct case on the point under companysideration is a decision of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Wealth Fax, Bombay City v. Purshottam N. Amersey and Another 2 . There the deed of settlement provided that the trustees shall apply he net income from the fund for the support, maintenance and advancement in life and otherwise for the benefit of the settlor and is wife etc.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Wealth Tax, Bombay City v. Purshottam N. Amersey and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: Rights to income for support and maintenance are assets within the definition under Wealth Tax Act; comprehensive inclusion of all assets in net wealth
precedents.cited_holding: The definition of assets in s. 2(e) and net wealth in s. 2(m) include every description of property barring exceptions
